questionOriginal: What is a coronavirus?
questionText: What is a coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. There are different types of coronaviruses.  Some types of coronavirus are more common in people and some versions are more common in animals. Rarely, a type of the virus that was common in animals can spread to people. "Coronavirus Disease 2019” (which is shortened to "COVID-19") is an example of a type of coronavirus that has recently spread to humans.     [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is novel (new) coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
questionText: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
answerOriginal: A "novel" virus means that scientists haven't seen this type of the virus before.  "Coronavirus Disease 2019” which is shortened to "COVID-19" is type of a virus that has never been seen before in humans.  [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]  When our body has seen a virus before either through a previous infection or through a vaccine, the body's defense system known as the "immune system" remembers how to fight off the virus if it sees it again. Because our body has never seen this virus before, our body's immune system has to learn how to fight off this new type of virus. While some of the symptoms of COVID-19 overlap with "common" cold or flu symptoms, it is caused by a different virus.

questionOriginal: What is COVID-19?
questionText: What is COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a new type of virus. Sometimes people also call it "coronavirus," which is is the type of virus that causes COVID-19. COVID-19 causes some symptoms that are like getting a cold or flu. But some people get worse symptoms and need more care. COVID-19 is caused by a new type of virus that our body has not seen before. Since our body has not seen it before, our immune system has to learn how to fight off this new virus.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is SARS-CoV-2?
questionText: What is SARS-CoV-2?
answerOriginal: SARS-COV-2 is the name for the virus that causes the disease known as "COVID-19." Let's break it down.  "SARS" stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome", meaning that it can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs.    "COV" stands for "Coronavirus." This is the type of virus that causes COVID-19.   The "2" is a way to say that this virus is different than the SARS virus that caused an outbreak in 2002-2003. questionText: Why are there two names for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: SARS-CoV-2 is the name for the virus that causes COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 is usually used when people talk about making new tests, vaccines, and medicines. questionOriginal: What is MERS-CoV?
questionText: What is MERS-CoV?
answerOriginal: MERS-CoV is one type of coronavirus. It is different type from the type of coronavirus that causes COVID-19. MERS-CoV stands for "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- associated Coronavirus."  The first cases of MERS-CoV were seen in 2012 in Saudi Arabia. MERS-CoV symptoms are fever, cough, and shortness of breath. People with this disease usually do not get sick from one another unless they are in very close contact.  [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: When is COVID-19 going to stop?
questionText: When is COVID-19 going to stop?
answerOriginal: Unfortunately, we do not know when COVID-19 will stop. questionOriginal: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The most important thing is to wash your hands. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol.     Here are some other things you can do to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19:    - Clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot, like tables, counters, light switches, door knobs, and cabinet handles.   - Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues and throw the tissue away.   - Stay at home if you are sick.   - Don't get too close to people who are sick.   - If "social distancing" measures are in effect where you are, be sure to follow them.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: What is a virus?
questionText: What is a virus?
answerOriginal: A virus is a very small particle that infect other cells. Viruses that infect people can make them sick.  Viruses are tiny, smaller than bacteria or fungi. They are small pieces of genetic material (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein shell. Viruses cannot survive long on their own. They need to use a living cell to live and reproduce. Once a virus enters a cell, it takes over that cell and uses it to make more viruses that go on to infect other cells.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
questionText: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
answerOriginal: There are a few reasons why people are very concerned about COVID-19. First, it is a new virus that humans have never had before. Our bodies haven't learned how to fight it off yet. Second, the virus is very infectious and has spread quickly around the world. Third, about 1 out of every 5 people who gets COVID-19 needs medical care in a hospital. Some hospitals will have trouble caring for this many sick people at the same time. Fourth, doctors and scientists still don't know very much about COVID-19 or how to treat it yet. Everyone is learning more every day.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for serious illness?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
questionText: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
answerOriginal: The main differences between viruses and bacteria are:  1. Viruses need to infect other cells to reproduce. They can't reproduce on their own. However, bacteria can reproduce on their own. 2. Viruses usually can't survive on their own as long as bacteria. 3. Viruses are much smaller than bacteria. 4. Most viruses cause disease. Some bacteria cause disease and some do not. 5. Viruses are usually more specific than bacteria about the kinds of cells that they attack in the body. For example, the virus that causes COVID-19 mostly affects cells in the respiratory system (the parts of the body involved in breathing)  [[Would you like more information about What is a virus?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a pandemic & epidemic?
questionText: What is the difference between a pandemic & epidemic?
answerOriginal: A pandemic is a global outbreak of disease that affects many people in different places.  An epidemic is an outbreak in a certain area or among a specific group of people over a particular period of time.   [[Would you like more information about Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?]]

An epidemic is an outbreak in a certain area or among a specific group of people over a particular period of time. questionOriginal: Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?
questionText: Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?
answerOriginal: The World Health Organization, or WHO, declared the COVID-19 outbreak to be a pandemic because it was likely that the virus was going to spread to all countries in the world. Declaring COVID-19 to be a pandemic helps to alert countries to prepare for the virus.   [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between a pandemic & epidemic?]]

questionOriginal: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
questionText: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
answerOriginal: The death rates are different between countries for a few reasons. The main reason is because some countries have tested more people than others.   Death rates can seem higher in countries where fewer people are tested. That's because death rates compare the number of people who have died from a disease to the number of people who have the disease, whether they die or not. When countries only test patients who are sick enough to go to the hospital and are not testing those who are less sick, this makes death rates seem higher than they are.

questionOriginal: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
questionText: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
answerOriginal: If you only have mild symptoms, it is safest to stay home. Most people with mild symptoms from COVID-19 are able to recover at home without medical care.  To keep the virus from spreading, you should: -Avoid public areas -Stay home, except to get medical care -If you think you need to go to the clinic or hospital, call before you go.    If you get one of these severe symptoms, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away -Starting to feel confused -Lips or face look blue

questionOriginal: Will humanity survive COVID-19?
questionText: Will humanity survive COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Together, we will survive COVID-19! Scientists and doctors are working very hard to find treatments and vaccines to help protect people from this virus.
answerText: Together, we will survive COVID-19! Scientists and doctors are working very hard to find treatments and vaccines to help protect people from this virus.

questionOriginal: What is the impact of COVID-19?
questionText: What is the impact of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is likely impact our lives in many ways. On the community level, this oubreak might lead to a decrease in polarization, more trust in science, and less individualism. On a lifestyle-level, this outbreak has moved even more of our activities online and might be a new boon to virtual reality. In terms of our health, there is likely to be a rise on telemedicine and an opening stronger family care. It is quite obvious that the global economy has taken a big toll due to COVID-19. Some experts say that there will be more restraints on mass consumption, stronger domestic supply chains, and a widening of the inequality gap, following the pandemic.

questionOriginal: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?
questionText: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?
answerOriginal: There is a lot left to be learned about this virus and how, when, and whether it will go away like previous outbreaks. However, in an absence of vaccines and effective treatments, the best thing we can do to practice social distancing, take care of ourselves, and stay hopeful.
answerText: There is a lot left to be learned about this virus and how, when, and whether it will go away like previous outbreaks. However, in an absence of vaccines and effective treatments, the best thing we can do to practice social distancing, take care of ourselves, and stay hopeful.

questionOriginal: How many asymptomatic people are there globally?
questionText: How many asymptomatic people are there globally?
answerOriginal: This is quite a difficult question. Although there is not an authoritative of asymptomatic cases globally, it is estimated that 25 percent of people infected with the new coronavirus don't present any symptoms or fall ill but can still transmit the illness to others.

questionOriginal: What are respiratory droplets?
questionText: What are respiratory droplets?
answerOriginal: Respiratory droplets are little drops that come from your nose or mouth when you sneeze, cough, talk, or breathe. They can stay in the air, or they can be passed from one person to another by touching commonly used surfaces such as door knobs, elevator buttons and faucets.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 can spread in a few different ways. It can spread from person to person if you inhale an infected person's respiratory droplets when they sneezes, coughs, or talk. It can also spead if you touch something that an infected person has touched, like a door knob, elevator button, or bathroom faucet.  That's why it's important to wash your hands, avoid touching your face, and practice social distancing to avoid getting sick. That's why it's also important to self-isolate and wear a mask around other household members if you are sick to avoid infecting other people.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]]

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be transmitted when a person is not showing symptoms?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be transmitted when a person is not showing symptoms?
answerOriginal: People might be able to spread the disease before people realize they are sick. But most scientists think that people are most likely to infect others when they have symptoms and feel sick.   Canada public health services is doing research to try to answer this question. questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
questionText: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
answerOriginal: We are still learning about how easily COVID-19 can transfer through the air. Small droplets can probably stay in the air for a short time after someone coughs or sneezes and those could infect someone. Also, some medical procedures can cause very small droplets that stay in the air for a longer time.  Scientists think that the main way you could get infected is if you were in close contact with an infected person and had your mouth, nose, or eyes exposed to infected respiratory droplets.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionOriginal: How long does the virus live on surfaces, like packages, plastic, etc? Should we be worried about that?
questionText: How long does the virus live on surfaces, like packages, plastic, etc? Should we be worried about that?
answerOriginal: In an experiment, scientists found that the virus could live:  -On plastic for up to 72 hours (3 days) -On stainless steel for up to 48 hours (2 days) -On cardboard for up to 24 hours (1 day) -On copper for up to 4 hours -In the air for up to 3 hours  Scientists still need to do more research to find out if these results also apply to the real world.  It is important to clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot.You should also wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use a hand sanitizer with at leat 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is community spread?
answerOriginal: Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.  [[Would you like more information about Is there COVID-19 in my area?]]

questionOriginal: What is "flattening the curve"?
questionText: What is "flattening the curve"?
answerOriginal: Flattening the curve means using socially distancing to prevent too many people from getting sick with COVID-19 at the same time. This helps to prevent the health care system from running out of enough staff and resources to care for everyone.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Why do I have to "socially distance"?
questionText: Why do I have to "socially distance"?
answerOriginal: Social distancing helps to reduce the chance of infecting people who are more likely to get severe disease. It helps to stop the virus from spreading quickly. This also helps to prevent there being too many sick people for hospitals to handle.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Why do I have to stay at home?
questionText: Why do I have to stay at home?
answerOriginal: Staying at home and using "social distancing" helps stop the virus from spreading quickly. This helps to reduce the burden on healthcare systems, as there are not enough hospital workers and beds if too many people get sick at once.  Social distancing means staying farther away from other people and avoiding groups of people. Since COVID-19 mostly spreads from person-to-person interactions, staying at least 6 feet away from other people can help stop the spread. It is important to use social distancing because people can spread COVID-19 even if they feel fine. It is especially important to use social distancing to protect people who are more likely to get very sick from the disease.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-isolation?
questionText: What is self-isolation?
answerOriginal: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-monitoring?
questionText: What is self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: Self-monitoring means that people should monitor themselves for fever by taking their temperatures twice a day and pay attention if they begin coughing or have trouble breathing. If they start to get symptoms during this self-monitoring period, they should self-isolate, limit their contact with others, and seek medical advice by telephone if possible.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
questionText: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: The difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation is based on whether you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or not. If you may have been exposed to COVID-19 but don't have symptoms, you should self-monitor. If you have been diagnosed with COVID-19, you should self-isolate.  You need to self-monitor if you have no symptoms but may have been exposed to COVID-19 in the last 14 days or are in close contact with older adults, people who are medically vulnerable or have been asked to do so by your Public Health Authority. Self-monitoring means you should:  -Monitor yourself for 14 days for symptoms like fever, cough, and trouble breathing -Stay at home -Avoid crowded places -Stay at least 6 feet away from others as much as you can -Wash your hands frequently  You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Continue to monitor your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What is social distancing?
questionText: What is social distancing?
answerOriginal: Social distancing means staying home and limiting contact with other people as much as you can. Social distancing is important because it reduces the spread of illness. You might need to change your habits to do social distancing well. For example:  -Avoid groups of people as much as you can -Don't shake hands or touch people to greet them -Don't go to crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences, or festivals -Stay away from people at high risk for severe symptoms, such as older people and those in poor health -Stay at least 2 arms' length (about 6 feet) away from others.  For example, if you need to buy groceries, limit this to once a week. If you go on walks, stay at least 6 feet away from others.

questionOriginal: Should I wear a mask?
questionText: Should I wear a mask?
answerOriginal: Face masks, including fabric ones, are likely only helpful in preventing people who have COVID-19 from spreading it to others. If you wear a cloth mask, you should still use the same social distancing measures as you would if you were not wearing a mask. This means you should stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people, wash your hands frequently, and avoid touching your face or eyes.  When wearing a mask, make sure it covers your nose and mouth. Wash the mask after you use it every time. When handling the mask, act as though the front of the mask is contaminated. Don't touch the front of the mask when you take it off or put it on.  It is not recommended that the general public wear surgical or N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra surgical or N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What are N95 respirators/masks?
questionText: What are N95 respirators/masks?
answerOriginal: This is a type of personal protective equipment that forms a tight seal around the nose and mouth to avoid airborne particles and fluid from entering. These masks are not "one size fits all" so people who depend on them for the job must get fit-tested before using them.   It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?]]

questionOriginal: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
questionText: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) are types of equipment worn to reduce the chance of someone getting a workplace injury or illness. Examples include gloves, safety glasses, shoes, earplugs or muffs, hard hats, respirators, coveralls, etc.   PPE is very important during this pandemic because there are not enough face masks for frontline health workers.  [[Would you like more information about What are N95 respirators/masks?]]

questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 contagious? Can someone who has it spread it to others? (How contagious is the virus?)
questionText: Is COVID-19 contagious? Can someone who has it spread it to others? (How contagious is the virus?)
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is contagious and it is actively spreading from person to person. The CDC recommends that those who have COVID-19 are isolated either at a hospital or at home, depending on how sick they are, until they are no longer at risk of infecting others.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What is community transmission?]]

questionOriginal: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
questionText: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: We aren't sure exactly how long people are contagious from COVID-19. If you have been sick with COVID-19 and have been in isolation, you should talk to your healthcare provider to decide when you can be released from isolation. Your doctor will look for signs that:  -You are fever-free without taking fever-reducing medication -You no longer show symptoms -Sometimes, your doctor might recommend testing respiratory samples to decide if you can be released from isolation  Once you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to be likely to infect other people.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: How long after being asymptomatic are you no longer contagious?
questionText: How long after being asymptomatic are you no longer contagious?
answerOriginal: If you think that you've been exposed to COVID-19, and are asymptomatic, you should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks, from the time that you think you might have been exposed. That's because most people who get COVID-19 show symptoms within 14 days. questionOriginal: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
questionText: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
answerOriginal: Yes, the virus can spread from person to person during incubation period. The “incubation period” means the time between catching the virus and beginning to have symptoms of the disease. If you may have been exposed to the virus and do not have any symptoms, please self-quarantine. If you are having COVID-19 symptoms, please self-isolate.   [[Would you like more information about what is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about what is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about what are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
questionText: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
answerOriginal: You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Continue to monitor your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days. Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
questionText: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
answerOriginal: If the infected person lives with others, it is important to keep them apart from others as much as possible. This means they should stay in another room as much as they can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  If you are living with someone who is infected, you should:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
answerOriginal: Right now, our current understanding of how COVID-19 spreads is primarily through person-to-person transfer of respiratory droplets. Studies are being conducted to understand how long Coronavirus lives on surfaces. In general, it is best to practice good food hygiene and good food safety practices. This means cleaning frequently used surfaces often, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. It is also important for all household members to wash hands frequently with soap and water before handling food.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
answerOriginal: Recent studies show in laboratories, COVID-19 can last on surfaces. However, with time, the amount of infectious virus decreases. So, it is possible that if someone touches a surface that has the virus on it and then touch their mouth, nose, or eyes that they can get the infection. However, this is thought to be less common than acquiring it through the transfer of respiratory droplets between two people.

questionOriginal: Is six feet a best practice, or is that a 100% safe zone?
questionText: Is six feet a best practice, or is that a 100% safe zone?
answerOriginal: Close contact with other people means being within six feet of each other. Maintaining a six foot distance between yourself and others (who may possibly be infected) can help reduce someone who is sick with COVID-19s transmission of the disease to someone is healthy. However, this does not mean that if you maintain a six foot difference from everyone, you will not get the virus.

questionOriginal: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
questionText: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
answerOriginal: No, herd immunity is not the only way to control COVID-19.   Herd immunity refers to when enough of the population is immune to an infectious disease (either through vaccinations and/or prior illness) that it makes it difficult for the disease to spread person to person. For COVID-19, that would mean that enough people develop immunity after acquiring the infection and reduce the person-to-person spread. However, if too many people become sick with COVID-19 at once, that will lead to more hospitalizations, an overburdened healthcare system, and more deaths. There is also still a lot that we do not know about COVID-19, including how long the immunity lasts.   Right now, it is best to practice social distancing, stay at home as much as possible, and practice frequent hand-washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If you do have to go out, maintain a 6 foot distance between yourself and others.

Right now, it is best to practice social distancing, stay at home as much as possible, and practice frequent hand-washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If you do have to go out, maintain a 6 foot distance between yourself and others.

questionOriginal: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
questionText: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
answerOriginal: Hand-washing is one of the best ways to keep yourself and your family from getting sick. Washing your hands well can remove all tarces of the virus on your hands. To wash your hands well,  use soap and water for at least 20 seconds.   Make sure to wash your hands:  - After blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing - After using the restroom - Before or after eating or making food - After being in a public place - After touching things that many other people have touched like door handles or tables  If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol. However, hand sanitizers do not get rid of all types of germs, so it is best to wash your hands as soon as you can.  [[Would you like more information about How does the COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
questionText: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
answerOriginal: The virus that causes COVID-19 is very susceptible to soaps so whenever washing clothes, it is important to use detergent. The CDC says you can also wash an infected person’s clothes with those of someone not ill, and advises using your regular laundry detergent and then drying the items thoroughly in the warmest temperatures recommended on the clothing label.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 kill people?
questionText: How does COVID-19 kill people?
answerOriginal: After entering the body, as the virus continues to replicate and journeys further down into the lung, causing pneumonia and inflammation. When pneumonia occurs, the thin layer of alveolar cells is damaged by the virus, triggering an immune response to fight it off. This immue response also results in the linings becoming thicker than normal, restricting oxygen to the bloodstream deprives other major organs of oxygen including the liver, kidney and brain. If too much of the lung is damaged and not enough oxygen is supplied to the rest of the body, respiratory failure could lead to organ failure and death.

questionOriginal: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: In general, a negative result means that the virus that causes COVID-19 was not found in the sample collected. However, sometimes if a person has COVID-19 in the early stages, it is possible that an initial test is negative but a test is positive later on when there is more virus present. You healthcare provider can help decide if you should be retested.

questionOriginal: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
questionText: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There is currently no vaccine or treatment  for COVID-19, and it might take some time to make one. Do NOT try to prevent or treat your COVID-19 symptoms using drugs like antibiotics. Talk to your doctor before starting a new medication. questionOriginal: What kind of medicine can I take to help ease the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What kind of medicine can I take to help ease the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Most people with mild coronavirus illness will recover on their own, or by treating the illness like the flu by using over-the-counter fever or pain relief medications. If you use non-prescription medications like acetaminophen (Tylenol) to ease symptoms, please follow the directions on the package and be aware of the warnings about interactions with alcohol and other drugs.   Please contact your health care provider before starting any new medications.

questionOriginal: Why are ventilators needed?
questionText: Why are ventilators needed?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 can make it hard to breathe, and in extreme cases, a person with COVID-19 may need help breathing using a ventilator. A ventilator is a machine that helps you take breaths and oxygenate your lungs if your body can not do it effectively on its own. Hospitals need enough ventilators to support patients who need help breathing due to COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How often should I take my temperature?
questionText: How often should I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: If you have been exposed to a person with COVID-19, or if you have reason to believe you have been infected, take your temperature two times a day (morning and night) every day for 14 days or whenever you feel like you may be feeling off and may have a temperature.

questionOriginal: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
questionText: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
answerOriginal: If you are high risk, stock up on supplies like nonperishable foods and medicines; if you must interact with others, take everyday precautions to keep space and distance between yourself and others; avoid people who are sick; avoid crowds, and wash your hands often with soap and water and avoid touching your face. Please limit travel and stay at home as much as possible. If there is an outbreak in your community, stay at home as much as possible and watch for symptoms and emergency signs. If you do get sick, call your doctor.   To learn more about how to prepare, click here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html

questionOriginal: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
questionText: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
answerOriginal: First, please remember that face masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and individuals who are exhibiting symptoms (e.g. cough, fever).   1. Before touching the mask, washing your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. 2. Take the mask and inspect it for tears and holes. 3. Orient which side is the top side (which is where the metal strip is) 4. Ensure that the proper side of the mask is facing outwards (the colored side) 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it is covering your mouth and chin 7. After use, take the mask off - remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 8. Discard the mask in a closed trash can immediately after use 9. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching / discarding the mask.

questionOriginal: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
questionText: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
answerOriginal: Given that the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product that shipped from China compared to anywhere else. Coronaviruses may be transmitted by touching a surface, but they are more likely to be transmitted through droplets. Overtime, the amount of infectious virus on a surface decreases. You can always wipe down any packages you may receive, allow a few days to pass before opening the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching packages.

questionOriginal: Can I donate blood?
questionText: Can I donate blood?
answerOriginal: Yes, as long as you are not sick and contagious. Donated blood is always needed, so if you are well and eligible, please consider donating. Blood centers, like the Red Cross, are being given guidance by CDC on how to keep donors and staff safe during this process.

questionOriginal: How can I and my family prepare for COVID-19?
questionText: How can I and my family prepare for COVID-19?

questionOriginal: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by staying at home as much as possibe and only going out whenever absolutely essential. If you do go out, you should try and maintain a 6 foot distance between you and other people. If you are sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or preparing food. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty. Please also clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).

questionOriginal: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
questionText: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If you are sick, stay at home except when you need to get medical care. If you experience difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, persistent pain or pressure in the chest, new confusion or inability to arouse, bluish lips or face, or any other concerns, please seek medical attention immediately. Please keep in mind that this is not the full list and if you're experiencing severe symptoms or something you are concerned by, please contact your medical provider.   If possible, use a separate room and bathroom for the sick household member. Try to have the sick family member maintain distance as much as possible. It will be important to make sure you clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Avoid sharing personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.

questionOriginal: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
questionText: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
answerOriginal: It is important to stay calm and put your preparedness plan into action. Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as possible (with at least a 6 feet distance between you and another person). It is important to stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through local health department. Please continue to practice handwashing, cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue, and frequently clean high-touch surfaces with regular household detergent and water.   It is important to also notify your workplace ASAP if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health condition, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you.   Please also stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.

Please also stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.

questionOriginal: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
questionText: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
answerOriginal: In most places, you can still go for a walk during a shelter in place order as long as you are abiding by your local state or county's rules. In general, here are a few tips:  -Stay at least 6 feet away from other people -Limit how long you will be outside, especially if there is a COVID-19 outbreak near you -Do not go to places where there are lots of people or crowds  This may not be allowed if you are in a location with strict quarantine measures. If you are or might be infected with COVID-19, you should not go for a walk outside, and should be self-isolating or in quarantine.   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]]

questionText: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
answerOriginal: Currently, there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19. questionText: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Handwashing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! This is important to do regularly - every time you wash your hands - but especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water available, please use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.

questionOriginal: Does the virus stay on clothing?
questionText: Does the virus stay on clothing?

questionOriginal: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
questionText: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If you are caring for someone with COVID-19 at home, prevent the spread of germs, treat symptoms, and monitor for emergency signs.  You can prevent the spread of germs at home by having the person stay in one room, away from other people (including yourself), as much as possible. Avoid having visitors and restrict contact with other people and pets. Avoid sharing personal household items like dishes and towels and have them use a separate bathroom if possible. If the person needs to be around other people, they should wear a facemask if available. If facemasks are available but they are unable to wear one, you should wear one when you need to be in the same room.   Prevent the spread of germs by washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after interacting with the sick person. If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Always avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.  Clean and disinfect all surfaces that are touched often, like tabletops and doorknobs, using household cleaning sprays or wipes. If laundry is soiled, wear disposable gloves and keep soiled laundry away from your body while laundering.   Symptoms of COVID-19 can be managed by staying hydrated and resting. For most people, symptoms last a few days and get better after a week. Keep track of symptoms (especially fevers) and contact the person’s healthcare provider if they are getting sicker. In the case of an emergency, call 911 and tell the dispatch personnel that the person has or might have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.   Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.   If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away  -Starting to feel confused  -Can't wake up from sleeping  -Lips or face look blue   If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]
answerText: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all. questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
questionText: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
answerOriginal: The symptoms of COVID-19 and flu are very similar. Both can cause fever, cough, and shortness of breath. To know for sure if you have COVID-19, you need to have a test from a doctor.   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
questionText: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
answerOriginal: If you think you had contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days (or two weeks) so that you don't spread the disease. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get symptoms 1 to 14 days after being exposed. If you have any symptoms related to COVID-19, you should self-isolate and talk to your health care provider. questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
answerOriginal: People are more likely to get a severe case of COVID-19 if they are:  -Older than 65 years old -Living in a nursing home or long term care facility -Pregnant -In a prison or jail  People are also more likely to get a severe case if they have a health problem such as:  -Lung disease -Asthma -Diabetes -Sickle cell disease -Liver cirrhosis (liver scarring) -Recent chemotherapy -A weaker immune system   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: From what doctors know now, children are not at a higher risk of Covid-19 than adults. Children can become sick with it, but not as often as adults. Most children who have gotten sick with COVID-19 have had mild symptoms, like fever, runny nose, and cough. Some have also had vomiting and diarrhea.  We are still learning if children with some underlying medical conditions may have a higher risk.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
questionText: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: By having them practice the same things you have to do! Washing hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, avoiding people who are sick, cleaning and disinfecting high touch surfaces in household common areas (e.g. tables, chairs, doorknobs, etc.), and laundering items like plush toys. It is also important to that your children try and socially distance from other individuals outside of your household. This means you should avoid playdates, allowing kids to get together physically with friends or playing on jungle gyms in public playgrounds.

questionOriginal: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
questionText: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
answerOriginal: No. They have the same symptoms, though it may be milder in children. Reported symptoms include cold-like symptoms, such as fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea have also been reported. There is more to be learned about how COVID-19 affects children.

questionOriginal: Should children wear masks?
questionText: Should children wear masks?
answerOriginal: Children under the age of 2 should not wear any type of masks. Because babies' airways are smaller, breathing through a mask is even harder on them and using a mask could increase the risk of suffocation. Older infants or young toddlers are not likely to keep the mask on and will likely try to remove it frequently; this will mean they are touching their face more and could infect themselves with the virus. The best course of action is to keep children at home and socialy distanced.

questionOriginal: Can I take my child to the playground?
questionText: Can I take my child to the playground?
answerOriginal: It is currently recommended to avoid if possible - as there are many germs at playgrounds. Your children can still play outside, but make sure they avoid gathering in large groups (more than 10 people), and that they wash their hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds.

questionOriginal: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
questionText: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
answerOriginal: It is important to talk with your child about what's going on. This is a stressful time for both children and adults, and children definitely will have questions. Talk to them about the outbreak, stay calm, and what you are doing as a family to stay safe.

questionOriginal: What steps should parents take to protect children during a community outbreak?
questionText: What steps should parents take to protect children during a community outbreak?
answerOriginal: If your child/children become sick with COVID-19, keep them home from daycare or school. Talk with teachers about their classroom assignments and how your child/children can continue work from home and keep up with school work. You should also talk to your child's medical provider to discuss when it is safe for your child to go back to school. While your child is sick, they must not leave the house and avoid physical contact with other siblings as much as possible. Continue cleaning frequently touched surfaces often and encouraging everyone to wash their hands with soap and water.

questionOriginal: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: School closings are a way that can help slow the spread of and reduce exposure to COVID-19. Please keep up with local news media sources, as they will share information about school dismissals. If schools are dismissed, your child should stay home and avoid gathering or socializing anywhere (like a friend's house, favorite restaurants, or local shopping malls). The purpose of closing schools down is to prevent students from silently passing the virus to each other, and then having students pass it to their families.

questionOriginal: I am pregnant, am I at a greater risk for more serious outcomes related to COVID-19?
questionText: I am pregnant, am I at a greater risk for more serious outcomes related to COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Doctors don't yet know for sure if pregnant women have a higher risk of having severe symptoms or long-term effects if they get COVID-19. Proper hygiene such as washing hands can help reduce the risk of getting infected of spreading the virus to others.  If you are pregnant and concerned about COVID-19, talk to your doctor. questionOriginal: I'm currently giving birth at a hospital in several weeks. Are there things that I should clean myself just in case? Also should I bring my own pillow and sheets for the hospital bed?
questionText: I'm currently giving birth at a hospital in several weeks. Are there things that I should clean myself just in case? Also should I bring my own pillow and sheets for the hospital bed?
answerOriginal: No, you do not have to bring your pillow and sheets for the hospital bed, as the hospital will ensure that everything is clean and sanitized. However, it is important that you are aware of certain policies hospitals are beginning to administer. For example, some hospitals are not allowing any visitors - which means your loved one, doula, etc will not be able to be beside you as you give birth. Please call your healthcare provider to get more information.   [[Would you like more information about what do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?]]

questionOriginal: Can you answer questions about pregnancy (how will hospitals handle prenatal visits, c sections, NICU, etc.) and those pregnant with additional health concerns (gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, etc.)? My OB and sonogram doctors are at UMB and I'm wondering if it’s worth the risk to go to some of my scheduled appointments. Are these nurses and doctors exempt from interacting with COVID-19 triaging and treatment?
questionText: Can you answer questions about pregnancy (how will hospitals handle prenatal visits, c sections, NICU, etc.) and those pregnant with additional health concerns (gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, etc.)? My OB and sonogram doctors are at UMB and I'm wondering if it’s worth the risk to go to some of my scheduled appointments. Are these nurses and doctors exempt from interacting with COVID-19 triaging and treatment?
answerOriginal: avoid public areas if possible and wear a face mask when out. Talk to your doctor about telemedicine, to avoid unnecessary visits to the office, except important pregnancy checkups. Consulting [your] doctors online is recommended. Many offices are already working to consolidate in-person appointments (for example, if someone is coming in for an ultrasound, a routine prenatal check might be added to the same visit)." (Qiao)   Consider how such a widespread outbreak could strain the health system, leading to disruptions in normal care. To prepare for that, have your medical records on hand. (Jamieson)   One big change that is already occurring in many labor and delivery wards is that they are limiting the number of visitors who can accompany anyone admitted for delivery — including through the postpartum stay. (ask your provider and the place where they intend to deliver about current rules on visitors. Typically the limit has been to one other healthy adult for the duration of the hospital stay.)   “Every pregnant woman and her family should have a plan, which should include what would happen if she or an additional caregiver gets sick." (ex. if a partner becomes ill with COVID-19 and is trying to self-isolate, is there another caregiver who can step in to help care for a newborn and mother?; because the illness is riskier for older adults, if the other caregiver might have once meant a new grandparent, a younger adult might be a better backup if possible.) (Jamieson)

questionOriginal: Can my dog/cat/pet/animal get COVID-19?
questionText: Can my dog/cat/pet/animal get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has not been clear evidence of the virus passing from humans to their pets at home. However, there was a tiger in a zoo in New York city that seems to have been infected with COVID-19 from it's caretakers. So it is important to always wash your hands before and after interacting with animals. The amount of information we know about human to animal transmission may change so talk to your pet's doctor if you want more information or are concerned about your pet's health.   Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal: avoid close contact with them, do not snuggle or kiss them, or let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed, practice good cough etiquette, avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals, have another member of your household care for your animals (if this is not possible, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them), and limit your animal's contact with other people and animals (this may mean keeping them indoors).

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
answerOriginal: Although the current spread and growth of the COVID-19 outbreak is primarily associated with spread from person to person, experts agree that the virus likely originated from bats and may have passed through an intermediary animal source in China before being transmitted to humans.  It is recommended that individuals who travel to avoid contact with animals, including wild meat and wet (live animal) markets.  If you are considering travel, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice prior to travelling.  Importers, rescue organizations and adoptive families should limit or postpone importing animals from affected areas. If animals are imported from an affected area: they should be closely monitored for signs of illness, you should contact a veterinarian if they become sick, and call ahead to ensure they are aware of the circumstances

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionOriginal: Should I avoid traveling?
questionText: Should I avoid traveling?
answerOriginal: If you are thinking about traveling, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice before you go. It is important to limit travel as much as possible.   If you think you need to travel, please go through these questions:   1. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you're going?  If it is, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay at home.   2. Will you or the people who you are traveling with be in close contact with others during your trip?  Your risk increases in crowded settings, especially closed-in settings that do not have good circulation. This includes conferences, concerts, etc.   3. Are you or your travel companion more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  People at higher risk for severe disease are older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart disease, lung disease, diabetes). If you are at higher risk, avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.   4. Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?  You may be asked to take time off, and be unable to go to work or school until you are considered non-infectious.   5. Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you get sick with COVID-19 while you travel, your family, friends, loved ones may be at risk of getting sick. People who are older and who have health problems are more likely to get very sick.  6. Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?  Even if you don't feel sick right now, you could pass on COVID-19 to others during travel without knowing it. This is very important if you'll be in contact with people who are older adults or have a severe chronic health problem. These people are at higher risk of getting very sick.   It is important to go through these questions to decide if it makes sense to travel.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there Covid in my area?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
questionText: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
answerOriginal: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to do the following:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days upon your return home.  2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with medical conditions who are higher risk of developing serious illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or difficulty breathing. 4. Wash you hand frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Dispose of tissue immediately, and wash your hands.   If you start to exhibit symptoms (e.g. cough, fever) within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate yourself from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and describe your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions carefully.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - such as persistent pain/pressure in chest, difficulty breathing, new confusion or inability to arouse, or bluish lips or face, seek immediate medical attention. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your own health and safety.

Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with medical conditions who are higher risk of developing serious illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or difficulty breathing. 4. Wash you hand frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer. 5. If your symptoms are severe - such as persistent pain/pressure in chest, difficulty breathing, new confusion or inability to arouse, or bluish lips or face, seek immediate medical attention. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your own health and safety.

questionOriginal: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
questionText: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, there is currently no known risk with being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19 as long as you continue to maintain a 6 foot distance. That being said, currently, we all must avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as possible.

questionOriginal: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
questionText: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
answerOriginal: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19.   We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes). Activities such as kissing, washing, and shrouding should be avoided before, after, and during the body being prepared. If washing and shrouding the body are important cultural and religious practices, families should work with their community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff on how to reduce exposure as much as possible. It is recommended that those conducting these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, additional personal protective equipment may be needed (like disposable gowns, goggles, face masks).

questionOriginal: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
questionText: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
answerOriginal: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.

questionOriginal: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has been a rise in stigma and hate crimes against Chinese and other Asian Americans, as well as people who were in quarantine. This is due to lack of knowledge around how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, as well as gossip that spreads rumors and myths.  [[Would you like to know more about COVID 19's stigma?]] Stigma hurts everyone as it creates more fear and anger towards ordinary people, instead of the disease that is causing the problem, or towards systems that are not supporting people in accessing screening and treatment. Sharing facts about how COVID-19 actually spreads can help stop stigma.

questionOriginal: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
questionText: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
answerOriginal: In order to stay safe while shopping, avoid close contact with others and keep six feet of distance with other shoppers. Avoid close contact while shopping include shopping at off-peak hours, wiping down the cart before and after use, and using debit or credit cards to avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. In areas where grocery delivery is not available, or is stretched to capacity, consider diversifying your procurement channels. In some areas, local farmers and producers may be offering direct purchasing options.

questionOriginal: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
questionText: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
answerOriginal: There is currently no evidence that supports the idea that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can survive on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, shoppers may consider disinfecting food packaging after bringing it home from the store, in addition to common-sense measures like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.
answerText: There is currently no evidence that supports the idea that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can survive on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, shoppers may consider disinfecting food packaging after bringing it home from the store, in addition to common-sense measures like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.

questionOriginal: What food should I eat to help boost my immune system?
questionText: What food should I eat to help boost my immune system?
answerOriginal: Five core micronutrients—vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, magnesium, and zinc—play roles in maintaining immune function. The best way to get vitamins and minerals is from a well-rounded diet, with plenty of fruits and vegetables (fresh or frozen are fine), legumes, whole grains, and lean sources of protein, along with healthy fats, such as nuts and olive oil.

questionOriginal: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
questionText: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
answerOriginal: Here are six practical ways to stretch your dollars at the grocery store.  Make Your Menu: Time permitting, write out a basic meal plan for the week and the groceries you’ll need for it.  Respect the Freezer : frozen fruits and vegetables are a cost-effective source of nutrition.  Play the Sale: Look for discounts, coupons, and sales, especially on store brands, which usually cost less.  Go Big: Buy in bulk when you can (e.g., purchase a whole chicken instead of just chicken breasts). Freeze what you don’t immediately need.  Go Home: If you have time, prepare food yourself instead of buying prepared or frozen meals. Thirty minutes will give you enough time to bring together simple, tasty meals.  Read the Fine Print: Compare unit prices (dollars per pound or per ounce) listed on price tags to find the cheapest brand.  Hold the Steak: Because meat can be a relatively expensive source of protein, look to supplement it with plant-based sources of protein like beans, quinoa, and whole-wheat pasta.  Shop the Season: Off-season produce is almost always more expensive and of inferior quality.

questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 spread in tropical conidtions
questionText: Does COVID-19 spread in tropical conidtions
answerOriginal: Temperate warm and cold climates are more favorable to spread of the virus, whereas arid and tropical climates are less favorable, according to a recent study which developed an ensembled of 200 ecological niche models to project monthly variation in climate suitability for spread of SARS-CoV-2. Important to note that model uncertainties are still high across much of sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and South East Asia

questionOriginal: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
questionText: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
answerOriginal: If you are worried about your mental health during this time, you are not alone.   Here are some ways to cope with stress that some people find helpful: 1. Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories. 2. Take breaks from social media. 3. Take care of your body by trying to eat healthy meals, exercising at home, and avoiding alcohol and drugs. 4. Make time to unwind and do activities you enjoy. 5. Spend time talking to others. If you have a phone or Internet access, call someone you trust and talk to them about how you are feeling.  If you are feeling overwhelmed by sadness, depression, or anxiety, please seek help from a trusted provider. If you have a mental health condition please continue your treatment. If you want or plan to harm yourself or others, please call an emergency number or hotline.

questionOriginal: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
questionText: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
answerOriginal: If you do not have soap and water, you may sanitize surfaces using a household disinfectant. Alcohol solutions that contain at least 70% alcohol may also be used. Please be sure to follow instructions on the product's label.  You may also be able to use a diluted bleach solution, depending on the surface you want to clean. Check the label to make sure you can use the solution for disinfecting and that it is not expired. Follow the instructions on the label and leave the solution on the surface for at least 1 minute. Please do NOT mix household bleach with ammonia or any other cleanser.

questionOriginal: How do I take my temperature?
questionText: How do I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: Your body temperature can be measured in many places on your body. The most common ones are the mouth, the ear, the armpit, and the rectum. Temperature can also be measured on your forehead.  To take your temperature using a digital thermometer, place the tip of the thermometer in your mouth, under the tongue and close to the middle. Keep the lips firmly closed and hold the thermometer in place with his tongue and fingers without biting it. You will hear a beep in about 30 seconds. Take the thermometer out and read the temperature.  In most adults, a fever is an oral temperature above 100.4°F (38°C) or a rectal or ear temperature above 101°F (38.3°C).

questionOriginal: Can I move during a pandemic?
questionText: Can I move during a pandemic?
answerOriginal: You should check with your moving company and local officials to see if there are travel or group restrictions that would prevent you from moving.  While you may be allowed to move during COVID-19, please consider the following things to determine whether it is in your best interest:  - Is your current home unsafe or uninhabitable?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If moving is essential, these same questions can help you plan your relocation to be as safe as possible.

While you may be allowed to move during COVID-19, please consider the following things to determine whether it is in your best interest:  - Is your current home unsafe or uninhabitable?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If moving is essential, these same questions can help you plan your relocation to be as safe as possible.

questionOriginal: Can coronavirus live in refrigerator
questionText: Can coronavirus live in refrigerator
answerOriginal: It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a packaging container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. This is not the main way the virus spreads. There is low risk of spreading coronavirus from food products or packaging.  Currently, there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food. Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds for general food safety.
